description: Quake II: Colossus is a compilation for Linux that includes Quake II and its add-ons, The Reckoning and Ground Zero. It is the first commercial Linux release of Quake II, which previously had only been available as a binary download, requiring the data files from the Windows release to function.
title: Quake II: Colossus

description: This wholly character-graphics free software game retains elements of Atari's classic Moon Patrol. Like its predecessor, this title sees a little lunar cart rolling across a moonscape. Furthering similarities not only in theme but gameplay, it also features bounding in low gravity over potential crash-causing craters and shooting at extraterrestrial navigational hazards through the use of keyboard commands.
title: Moon-Buggy

description:
The Special Edition of X³: Reunion for Linux comes in an old-style big game box containing:

  • the regular X3 game;
  • an X³ T-shirt;
  • a copy of the book "Farnhams Legend".

Each one of the 500 limited edition copies is numbered and signed by the CEO of LGP.
title: X³: Reunion (Special Edition)

alternate_titles.title: Z-tornado: A two-player weather action game; Yet another abuse of the Z-Machine

description:
A final adaptation of the PET's venerable Ouranos!, this version backslides in terms of graphics quality but offers one new play innovation.

The general premise is that two feuding neighbors inhabit nearby buildings and for whatever reason are able to take turns harnessing the destructive powers inherent in their local weather system, using them to harass their nearby opponent, wearing their houses down with violent forces from the sky. Traditionally these include rain, hail, lightning and tornadoes; in this version these are joined by one new defensive weather type, snow, which when properly aimed can coat your building with a soft and protective layer that insulates against hail damage.

The weather emanates from a cloud that randomly ambles now here, now there across the top of the screen between turns. With wind speed also variable, players need to input a number informing the angle at which the weather should be discharged from the cloud, hopefully so as to land on their opponent's house. When one house is wholly demolished, the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Snow leaves a protective coating in its wake
High score table
Keys
Instructions
Game menu

title: Tornado

description:
This collection contains about 1,000 open source and freeware games for Linux, about 300 development libraries useful for game development and several common utilities and HOWTOs. Most of the programs are available as source code and have to be extracted and compiled before usage, a few games are also available as RPM packages.

The CDs' contents are browsable via a HTML page which splits the software into several categories; the category links refer to the corresponding location on CD, which can in turn be accessed through the browser's directory listing. Further information about the games (e.g. a game description or screenshots) is usually not available.

The CDs contain the following categories:

  • CD 1:
    • Games for beginners
      • Debian games
      • EasyLinux games
      • RedHat games
      • Game collection for console
      • Game collection for GNOME
      • Game collection for KDE
      • Game collection for X-11
      • Game collection for X-Windows
      • Miscellaneous games collection
    • Games for children
  • CD 2:
    • Linux libraries
    • Linux Special
      • Manuals (containing German HOWTOs)
      • Joystick
      • Linux Demoscene
      • Netscape 470
      • Virus scanners
    • Games for advanced users
      • Acarde+Video
      • Action
      • Adventure
      • Amusment
      • Blockout
      • Cards
      • Chess
      • CrossWords
      • Dungeon
      • Emulators
      • Esoteric
      • Life Games
      • LinuxCRAFT
      • Mahjongg
      • MUDs
      • Multiplay + Network
      • PacMan
      • Puzzle + More
      • Role Playing
      • Simulation
      • Solitare
      • Sport Games
      • Strategy
      • Tamagotchi
      • Tetris
      • Text Adventures
      • Various
      • Wargame

sample_screenshots.caption: Overview of the beginners games category. Most sections have further subcategories, however those don't have separate HTML pages and have to be viewed with the browser's file browser instead.
Overview of the games for advanced users.
Games are usually only available as source code without any further instructions. Here you also find a .lsm file with a short summary similar to .NFO files often found on FTP / BBS servers.
Start page of CD 2
Browsing the "Strategy" section with the browser's integrated file browser.

title: Linux Spiele & Games

alternate_titles.title: play it! ...the funny side of Linux!

description:
This CD contains a collection of 69 open source and freeware games of various genres for Linux. The games are presented with a short description and a screenshot of each game on a HTML site; with the exception of NetHack all games can be started directly from CD without installation.

The following games are included:

  • Penguin Command
  • XPilot
  • XBlast
  • ZLOE
  • Mirror Magic
  • Rocks 'n' Diamonds
  • Roll 'm Up
  • Black Penguin
  • Blockade

  • The Ace of Penguins game collection by DJ Delorie
  • The "X Tetri" versions of the Altris Tetris variants and xpuzzles rotational 3D and sliding block collections by David Bagley

The collection also includes the source code of most of the open source games.

title: play it! Linux: Die Spielesammlung ...the funny side of Linux!

description:
This compilation contains 54 games of various genres for Linux plus several libraries commonly used for gaming. The programs are usually provided in source code form, however some of them also include binary or RPM files.

The games are presented on HTML pages grouped by genres, providing a link to the game's archive on disc and a short game description.

The following games are included:

title: Linux Spiele

description:
This compilation contains over 100 open source games, emulators and tools for Linux. Almost all of them are included in source code form, some of them are also provided as binary or RPM files. Additionally almost 100 development libraries useful for game development are included.

The included programs are split into the categories "Software development" and "Entertainment" and presented on HTML pages containing a short textual description of the program and potential special library dependencies.

Among others (the "Entertainment" list mixes games, tools and emulators) the following games are included:

  • BlockOut

Development libraries - this time the English version.
"Entertainment" category; games, emulators and tools are all thrown together into the same category.

title: Linux: Spiele und Entertainment für X Windows

description:
KMahJongg is a Mahjongg-Solitaire implementation. The player has to clear a board filled with 144 stones by removing pairs with the same symbol. You are only allowed to remove a pair if both stones are "free", which means they do not have stones connected on both left and right side or a stone above them.

There are six different graphical tile set available, including the traditional set. Beside the default "turtle" layout, there are over 70 board layouts to chose from. The game comes with a board editor, which makes it easy to create own board layout. The game has a hint system, indicating you pairs to find. Using hints prevent the scores to be added to the high-score table. The game can be configured to create solvable board situations (many randomly created Mahjongg boards cannot be cleared with any sequence of removed pairs). Required time, removed pairs and the amount of currently possible removals are always shown on the bottom of the window. games are load- and savable, the high-score list is persistent and you can start a board with a game number, which allows to re-create a certain board situation (which also means you can exchange boards with other people by giving them this random seed).

KMahJongg is part in the KDE game module which is usually included in the any installation of the KDE desktop (but the game is also playable on any other Linux desktop system and can be installed on it's own).

sample_screenshots.caption: Alternative layout, tileset and background
The letter tile-set is recommended for beginners
Another board layout
Board editor
Default layout and tile set (version 0.8)

title: KMahJongg

description:
KShisen is an implementation of the Shisen-Sho/Match-It coin-op. Stones are places on a flat rectangular board and have to be removed by pairs of the same symbol. Each symbol applies four times on the board. Pairs can be removed if the connection between them can be made with a line that only can be drawn horizontally or vertically with maximal two corners.

The board size can be configured, from 84 stones (14x6) up to 480 stones (30x16). The default size are 144 stones like in most other Mahjongg games. Beside the board size, the difficulty can be set in three steps from easy to hard. The game can be configured to only produce solvable boards (many boards created randomly are not solvable with any sequence of pairs removed). An extension called "Chinese style" allows the removal of stone groups, like a flower can match all other flowers and not only it's identical flower symbol. If you are stuck, you can get hints by the program, but high-scores are locked if you are doing so.

An extension to the original game, the game is using gravity by default, that means stones are falling in removed spots from top to bottom (like in Tetris). Gravity can be turned off.

The game shares its six graphical tile sets as well as the background graphics with its cousin KMahJongg.

KMahJongg is part in the game module which is usually included in the installation of the KDE desktop (but the game is also playable on any other Linux desktop system and can be installed on its own).

sample_screenshots.caption: Game options: gravity, "Chinese mode", board size and difficulty can be set to your personal preferences
The smallest board (14x6) allows very short games
Creating a very huge (30x16) board
Default board size with default tile set (Version 1.8.4, 2013)
You can only reach the high-score table by clearing the board completely

title: KShisen

description:
KFourInLine is an implementation of the Connect Four board game. On a 6x7 board, players can add stones in turns, trying to get four connected stones of the same color in either horizontal, vertical or diagonal ways.

The game features four graphical sets, a two player mode and a self-learning AI for single player games. The difficulty of the game can be adjusted by setting the AI 7 possible settings from "Easy" to "Hard". The game can give you hints about the best stones to place. Two player games can be played in a hot-seat playing mode on the same computer, but the game is also featuring a network mode, in which one of the computers generate a local server. Chatting with the other player connected via network is possible.

Moves can be taken back (Undo), games can be saved and stored and some basic statistic about the games played can be displayed.

The game is specifically made for the KDE desktop environment, but can also be installed on any other desktop environment.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title screen with basic menu (KDE 5, game version 1.40)
Options window: set names, AI strength, and player control
First game
Maybe there is a trap?
I think not. But I am simply blind.

title: KFourInLine

description:
Bomber is a variant of the Atari coin-op Canyon Bomber from 1977. A plane is constantly moving from the left to the right and reappearing on the left side after reaching the right border. With each line, the plane is loosing some height. On the ground there are towers which has to be destroyed before the plane is reaching the ground, which can be done by dropping bombs from the flying plane.

As the plane is moving automatically, a single button for dropping bombs is enough to play Bomber. After clearing all obstacles on the ground the game continues in a higher level. With each level progressed, the speed of the plane is increased and the towers on the ground are higher, making the game more difficult.

There are two theme sets: on with a plane and towers, and another with a zeppelin which has to destroy rocks in a lava landscape.

sample_screenshots.caption: Lost lots of height and still many stones around
High-score table
Title screen
Playing the lava level. You now control a zeppelin and destroy stones
Simple thing: drop some bombs!

title: Bomber

description:
KSquares is an implementation of the pen and paper game Dots and Boxes. On a grid each player connect two points with a line each turn. The goal is to connect four lines to create a square. Filling a square allows the player to add another line to the grid instantly, making it possible to fill many squares in one turn. The game ends if all grid points are connected, and therefore all squares are filled. The player with most filled rectangles wins.

The KSquare game can be played with different board sizes from a very tiny 2x1 fields up to a very large board of 50x30 fields. Up to four players can compete locally, any missing players may be filled with an player controlled by the computer. The playing level of those AI opponents can be altered in three degrees from "Easy" to "Hard". The game is featuring a "Quick Start" mode, in which there are many lines already connected, which results in much faster action by skipping the repetitive starting phase. A high score table is present and can be persisted.

sample_screenshots.caption: In becomes some kind of abstract art
Starting with an empty board of medium size (20x10)
The final result of the AI game
Quick starting games has many lines already on the board, so the repetitive starting phase is skipped
Four AI players compete on the maximum size board

title: KSquares

description:
Pacman is an conversion of the classic Pac-Man game. Like in the original, you are controlling the circled sprite on it's way through the maze and eating all dots lying around. You finish the level if you ate all of those dots. But there are four ghosts wandering around in the labyrinth which must be avoided. There are four power pills in the edges of the maze, which give you some seconds in which you can kill the ghosts.

The game is featuring a single maze, which restarts on level completion with more aggressive ghosts. If you clear the level faster, you get more bonus points (the bonus score is ticking downwards constantly). The time to chase the ghosts after eating a power pill is shown as counter, too. There are two extra items, which are rewarding the player some extra points or an additional life.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game start
After eating the power pill you can hunt the ghosts

title: Pacman

description:
KBounce is an arcade game with a puzzle element. The single-screen levels are made of blocks, with walls around the inner field. The goal is to fill 75% of the inner field with blocks. Creating blocks can be done by starting either horizontal or vertical lines by clicking on a block in the field. From the selected block and chosen direction, two new walls are growing until they reach the next solid wall. But there is a problem: in the level there are balls, moving and bouncing of each solid stone they encounter. If they hit a growing wall, you loose a life and the created wall part vanishes. If they however touch the head of a growing wall, the wall continues to grow and the ball bounces of like it touched a wall. As the new wall is growing in two directions from the selected spot (e.g. up and down for a vertical line), only the part of the growing wall that was hit is consumed. This allows partial construction of lines and building of separators in the level. If a line finally reaches a wall and there is a closed area created with no ball inside, that area is filled with new blocks.

Each level has an increasing amount of balls flying around. Starting with two balls in level one, there are eleven balls in level ten. Also, the amount of lives is no session counter, but set to the amount of balls in that level. This means in higher levels there are always more lives available and those can be used strategically to build partial constructions. There is also a time limit, which is increasing with each level solved. You earn bonus points for remaining lives and time at the end of a level. A high-score table can be reached and saved. The player can chose from six different graphical tile sets and the game difficulty can be set in three steps from "Easy" to "Hard".

sample_screenshots.caption: Such lines appear if one of the growing parts was hit by a ball - this is a useful technique to split the field
It's game over for me. But it's the green theme, so there may be hope...
Finishing a level is rewarded with bonus points for remaining lives and time
The high-score table is initially empty
Although two areas were created, no fill happened because balls were inside each of them. But those separation lines are also helping a lot

title: KBounce

description:
KBreakOut is a Breakout variant with strong influences of Arkanoid. The player controls a bat at the bottom of the screen which can be moved left and right. In each level a formation of bricks has to be destroyed, by letting a ball bounce from your bat. Controlling the flight of the ball is like in most Breakout games: as closer the ball hits the bat at the border, the higher the angle the ball reflects. A life is lost if the ball passes the bottom border.

The game features many additional features: on destroying bricks, some random bonus items may drop, which can be collected by the bat. There are items rewarding extra points, extra lives, a wider bat or a ball with destroys all bricks around the stone it's hitting, there are also items with negative effect like a smaller bat or even instantly loosing a life. You can get multiple balls or items altering the stones in the level. The levels are constructed of different brick types, including stones initially not visible until hit, or bricks that explode on contact, destroying all stones around them.

The scoring system rewards points for each brick and each item collected. Passing a level grants you a bonus, but loosing a live decreases the score pointer by a huge amount. A high-score table can be reached.

sample_screenshots.caption: The first level in another graphical theme
Level 2
The manual shows all the stones, tricks and numbers
The high-score table is initially empty
Level 1 (Version 1.1.0)

title: KBreakOut

description:
KBlocks is a falling-blocks game like Tetris. Blocks of different shape are falling from the top of the screen and to sort them that horizontal lines are created at the bottom. If a line is build, it vanishes and the player is rewarded some points. The player can rotate the shapes falling down. The game ends if the stacked stones reaching the upper border.

There are three difficulty levels, with "Easy" starting at level 1, "Medium" at level 5 and "Hard" on level 10. With increasing levels, the falling speed of the blocks is increased, making sorting them harder. There are two graphical theme sets delivered with the game, but more can be downloaded directly from inside the game.

Beside the traditional single player game, there is a mode in which you play against the AI. Each block is identical for both the player and the AI and you can try to beat the computer by sorting the blocks better than it. In this game mode, the view is splitted and two playing fields are shown beside each other. Reaching a good score allows you to enter a high-score table, which is saved to disk.

sample_screenshots.caption: The AI clearly takes another strategy
In which the human failed in the end: due to biological constraints I was unable to turn the stones quickly enough
High-scores are saved for each difficulty mode separately
Even though, it is an even game
Playing against the AI: the AI is using the stone falling next on your side, you have to stack the stones better than the computer

title: KBlocks

description:
Kigo is an implementation of the Go board game for the KDE desktop environment.

The game can be played on any board size from tiny 9x9 up to the normal 19x19 board. Handicaps and Komi points can be set manually. Two players can play against each other, but there is also a computer AI taking over one or even two players. The AI engine can be exchanged with any implementation supporting the "GnuGo Text Protocol", with the gnugo engine delivered with the game. You can request the game to show you a hint about a good move, display the sequence of stones set. There are two graphical tile sets and a huge collection of historical Go games can be installed and loaded directly from the main interface.

sample_screenshots.caption: Finished game
Starting screen with tiny (9x9) board size (Version 0.5.6)
Naturally, games on the normal board (19x19) take much longer (also: switched to alternative theme)
As I am a lousy Go player, I let the AI battle itself
The sequence of settings can be turned on and off

title: Kigo

description:
Kiriki is an implementation of the Yahtzee dice game. The player throws five dices for up to three times, keeping back those dices already on a desirable number. The player has to fill 13 categories, like collecting specific numbers, building streets out of 4 or 5 successive numbers, or a full house with three of a kind and a pair. All rules from the original game are valid: you get a bonus of 35 if reaching at least 63 in the upper part. Reaching five of a kind is called "Kiriki" here, and also rewarded with 50 points.

Kiriki allows up to six players at the same time, of which any can be played by the computer. A high-score table can be reached.

sample_screenshots.caption: On the left you chose the dices to re-roll. If you are finished, simply click on the wanted category on the scoring sheet
The high-score table is initially empty
The random number generator grants me a favour

title: Kiriki

description:
Granatier is a Bomberman clone. Up to five players compete in an arena, trying to be the last man standing. On the game start, the arena is filled with stones, either destructible or indestructible. The player can drop bombs, which destroys any stone or player in four directions (up, down, left, right). Destroyed stones may drop items which enhance the size of your bomb explosions, grants you another bombs to drop at the same time, or makes the player move faster. There are also items which negatively affecting the player, like inverting the control or preventing you to drop bombs for a certain amount of time.

The game features 38 different arenas, which are partly containing special stones: on ice the player cannot stop and moves further until the next solid ground, arrows move bombs in a certain direction, or the bomb mortar, which throws a bomb planted on it in a random direction. Unlike the original game, not all mazes are surrounded by solid blocks, and the player instantly dies if running over the border of the level. The amount of rounds can be configured as well as the time for each round. Also, the initial speed of the avatars and the amount of bombs available can be configured to make the game start faster.

Granatier supports maps created for the game Clanbomber and can import those. The mazes are stored in a XML format which allows the creation of own levels, which is described in the manual. The game only features keyboard control, but although fully configurable, it may make a five player game difficult. There are no computer controlled bots to add to the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the middle, the level is open to the left and right. Beware running there too fast, you will fall and die if passing the last field
Found a bonus item which allows kicking of bombs (by running on them). Nice!
Lots of possibilities to fall of the platforms if all stones are removed in this level
The manual has extensive information about all items and stones
Another maze in another graphical theme

title: Granatier

description:
Kapman is an implementation of Pac-Man. In a single-screen maze the player has to collect all dots to finish a level. Four marauding ghosts are trying to prevent this. There are four power-pills in the edges of the maze, and after eaten one of those, the player can chase and kill the ghosts for a specific amount of time.

The game features the original maze and 20 levels, which are all played in the same maze, but both the speed of the ghosts and player are increased with the ghosts slightly getting more faster than you. The AI of the opponents is quite simple: if the ghosts can directly see the player (no walls in-between), they are directly coming for the player. If they cannot see the player, they are moving randomly. There are five different graphical themes, altering the graphics of the maze and the moving sprites. Playing the "Invisible" theme is a challenge, as all walls are invisible, and the player has to navigate with the dots or his knowledge of the maze layout. There are three different difficulty settings and the player can start on any level.

After 1/3 and 2/3 of the dots removed in the level a bonus item appears awarding 200 points. Chasing ghosts is the most effective way to gain points, as the first ghost is worth 200 points, the second 400 up to 800 for the fourth ghost captured during the seconds a single power-pill is active. Each 10.000 points an extra-life is gained. A high-score table can be reached.

sample_screenshots.caption: The matches theme
I got caught (in another graphical theme)
After eating a power-pill the ghosts can be killed (blue color)
Playing the traditional graphic theme. And an bonus item appeared which I should collect quickly
The manual describes all items and elements of the game

title: Kapman

description:
KReversi is an implementation of the Reversi-board game. On a 8x8 board two players set stones in turns and must place the new stone that at least one stone of the opponent is captured. This capturing happens for each stone of the opposite color that is in a connection to the new stone in either horizontal, vertical or diagonal lines. The game ends if no player can set a stone any more. The winner is that player with more stones on the board.

The game can be played with two human players, but also an AI can take the role of one or both players. The strength of the computer played can be set in seven levels from "Very easy" to "Impossible". Two different graphical stone sets are included. The game can show the legal moves and also give hints about good moves to make.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting position
The manual gives you some advice for the tactic
First moves
The board in with the alternative graphical stone set
The last move can also be marked visually

title: KReversi

description:
KDiamond is a tile-matching game, in which the player has to build rows or columns of at least three identical colors. This is done by exchanging to adjacent stones (horizontal or vertically, not diagonal). Overall there are six colors on the board. The board size can be configured by the game difficulty. In the "Very hard" setting the board is of the size 8x8, while in the "Very easy" mode the board has a size of 12x12. If stones are removed, all stones from above the position are falling down and the missing stones are replaced with random stones at the top. With clever planning (or simply luck) chain reactions of removed tiles are produced by the falling blocks.

The game can be played with or without time limit. If playing with time limit removing stones also grants some bonus time, so the end is not fixed, but can be extended by removing many tiles. KDiamond has different graphical tile sets and a high-score table. Hints can be shown on request and in the toolbar the amount of possible moves in the current board position is shown.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting board in the "Diamond" theme
Medium sized board
Theme selection
Difficulty "Very Hard": very small board, fewer options to find three matching tiles
The high-score table is initially empty. So even with 0 points the top was reached

title: KDiamond

description:
Kollision is a small arcade game. A room is filled with red balls, moving with constant speed and bounce of walls. If the red balls collide with each other, they change impulse (their speed) and direction according to the angles they hit. The player controls a blue ball freely with the mouse and has to avoid any contact with the other balls. If there is a contact, the game ends. The goal is simple: survive as long as possible.

After certain amount of time, an additional red ball is added to the game, making it more difficult to avoid the contact. There are three difficulty levels, which differ in the speed the red balls are moving. There is a high-score table with separate scores for each of the difficulty level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Another red ball added
Seven balls, it slowly gets full
In any difficulty level, the game starts with four red balls. Player controls the blue ball
Separate high-score tables are kept for each difficulty level

title: Kollision

description:
KSnakeDuel is an implementation of the Tron arcade game. Two players compete on a board moving around, but leave a solid trail after them, that do not disappear. Colliding with a wall, the tail of the opposite player or the own tail looses the round.

Beside the two player mode, in which either two human players can compete or a single player can play against a computer controlled snake, there is also a single player mode which plays differently. It makes the game more like a Snake variant: you control the head of your snake and the tail if not solid, but of a specific length. Collecting bonus crystals increases the size of the tail. Random obstacles are constantly appearing on the screen and a collision must be avoided.

In both modes, the game features five different difficulty levels, which change the speed both players are moving. There is a separate high-score table for each of the difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: On collecting yellow or blue crystals the tail grows
Another two player game in the alternative theme
Two player game: tails are solid and do not disappear
Single player game: you start as a snake without tail
Starting screen

title: KSnakeDuel

description:
KsirK is an implementation of the Risk-board game. Up to six players compete on a world map. Each turn armies can be set in own countries and other countries attacked. Attacking a country is implemented with dice throws. Depending on the amount of armies of the attacker, the attacker can throw up to three dices, while the defender throws up to two. The player with one or two of the highest numbers throws wins the duel and an army of the opposite is removed.

The goal of the game can either be set to world domination, in which a single player has to conquer all countries to win. And you can play with missions to clear, e.g. conquer three specific continents or invade a certain amount of countries. Each turn new armies are rewarded based on the amount of countries under the control of the player. Owning all countries of a continent like Europe or Australia, additional armies are rewarded.

KsirK is a very straight implementation, even keeping the dice model and the mission goals from the original game. Up to five players can be controlled by the computer. Multi-player games can either be played in hot-seat mode locally or through a network game. Games can be saved and loaded.

sample_screenshots.caption: Fighting if optionally shown in an animated arena (but based on the dice rules of risk)
With the goal to conquer Asia and North America, things does not look too bad, as Australia is a good starting point for this
Opponents are chosen. I will conquer the world with Belgium (image that fuzzy in the game)
Starting screen with main menu
The world map: flags indicate the owners of the specific countries

title: KsirK

description:
Killbots is an extended implementation of the older UNIX game robots by Ken Arnold. The player is chased by robots trying to kill him. The goal is to survive until all robots are dead. In this turn-based program the player can move his avatar in all eight directions over the board. In each round, the robots make a step in the direction of the player. If they touch him, the game is over. But the robots are also deadly to themselves: if they touch each other, they turn into a pile of garbage and this pile is also deadly for other robots. So to kill the robots, the player has to move that the robots touch each other or running into garbage piles. If there is no way out, the player can teleport to a randomly location on the board. Teleporting is consuming energy, which can be refilled by destroying robots or completion of a level.

Killbots implements additional game elements taken from the game Gnome Robots, like fast-bots, which can move two fields in a round and save teleports, in which the destination cannot be directly beside a robot. Another addition is the vaporizer, which lets you destroy robots. Also junk piles may be pushed. There are five game modes, which feature different rule sets, the additional features and have different board sizes and also differ in the energy consumption. There is one mode with the same rule set and board sizes like in the original game, a mode in which the energy cannot be refilled, a mode with the vaporizer to use. Another mode mimics the rule set of the Apple game Daleks. And there is a beginner mode, in which the board is randomly filled with garbage. There are four different graphical tile sets including one with the graphics of the text console display of the original game.

A high-score table can be reached.

sample_screenshots.caption: In such situation teleporting helps :)
In later levels, the "fast-bots" (green) appear, moving two fields in one turn
The "Easy" game type with lots of junk randomly on the board
Robots collided: they leave junk. Moving up now would cause on robot run into the garbage also killit it
Default game type with default tile set. My guy is starting in the middle

title: Killbots

description:
Klickety is a conversion of the game Clickomania. You have a board filled with colored stones and the goal is to clear the board completely. You can remove stones when at least two stones of the same color are beside each other. On a removal, all stones adjacent in vertical and horizontal directions are also removed. The stones above the removed spot are falling down filling the holes (like in Tetris, but no new stones appear).

If a complete column is cleared, the column is removed making the board more narrow, so stones from the left over columns can be removed. Completely clearing the board required good planning and a bit luck. The amount of leftover pieces if no more removals are possible is counting as a score and is recorded in a high-score table, separated by the difficulty level. There are four difficulty levels. While in the "Very easy" setting only three colors are on the board, in the highest difficulty level "Very hard" there are six colors. Games can be saved, and the random seed can be set for a level so the exactly same boards can be reproduced.

sample_screenshots.caption: Final blink on the board: four stones couldn't be removed
Medium difficulty shown in the second theme
A column was cleared and the board becomes more narrow
The highest difficulty with six colors shown in the third graphical theme
Starting board ("Easy", 4 colors). Any colored are with at least two stones can be removed

title: Klickety

description:
KAtomic is a conversion of the puzzle game Atomix from 1990. The player has to build molecules out of atoms distributed in the level. Each atom has one or multiple connectors, either horizontal, vertical or diagonal. By putting together the atoms with the corresponding connectors, the molecule can be finished. The player can move each atom, and it will move in the chosen direction until a wall or another atom is hit so that it is often required to move additional atoms to places just to use them as "stoppers".

The game is featuring three different level packs: the original levels from KAtomic with 83 levels in increasing difficulty. An extension pack with another 25 levels and finally all 30 levels from the original Atomix game. Games can be saved and loaded. Moves can be taken back (Undo and Redo). If you loaded a game, you can switch between the levels freely.

sample_screenshots.caption: Clicking on an atom shows directions you can move it (either by mouse or keyboard)
Assembled the first molecule
With the Ethylene molecule the first atom with diagonal connectors appeared
Placing the blue atom was essential to solve this
Level two has a four way connector (In the upper right corner the final build is shown)

title: KAtomic

description:
KJumpingCube is a puzzle/strategy game played on a squared board. A board is filled with cubes and the goal is to recolor all of them to win the game. Each cube has a certain amount of stones laying on it giving it a numerical value. Starting the game, the board is filled with neutral colored cubes of value 1. Clicking on a neutral field transforms this cube to the players color and gives it value 2. Each turn, one own or neutral cube can be selected. Choosing an own stone increases it's number. If a cube has a higher value than neighbors in horizontal or vertical way, the cube unleashes one point to all neighbors (keeping one on it's own), recoloring to the players color and adding one to their value. This can lead to huge cascades as for each cube an stone is added another check is done and it may spread too.

The game can be played on board sized 3x3 up to 15x15, either with two human players or with computer players with five different strength levels and two alternative strategies. The game can provide hints about good spots to select cubes. Moves may be taken back with an undo function and games can be saved and stored.

sample_screenshots.caption: Green counters with an attack on the lower side
Game on a very small board
Game on the biggest possible board
Medium sized board after first two moves (brown cubes are neutral, green and blue the players)
Suddenly blue is in the defense

title: KJumpingCube

alternate_titles.description: Former title (still used on the websites and executable name)
alternate_titles.title: KLines

description: Kolor Lines is a conversion of the game Color Lines. The goal of this board game is to build lines of at least 5 stones of the same color in either vertical or horizontal direction. The game starts with an empty board and each turn, three new stones appear on random locations. Each turn, the player can move one stone. If can be moved to any free spot which is accessible through a route by moving without diagonal moves. If a line of five or more stones is created, it disappears and some points are rewarded. The game ends if there is no more free spot. The game shows the next three stones appearing on the board on the right side. A high-score table can be reached.

sample_screenshots.caption: The board in another graphical theme
And the fourth theme
A nearly filled board
Yet another graphical theme
The starting position with the first batch of three stones arrived

title: Kolor Lines

description:
KMines is an implementation of the classic Minesweeper game for the KDE desktop. On a rectangular board there are bombs hidden in random spots. The player has to reveal fields and if at least one bomb is around that field in any of the eight directions of the board, the number of surrounding bombs is shown as a number. If no bomb is around that field, the field is cleared and all adjacent fields without any bomb contact are also revealed. The goal of the game is to mark all fields with bombs by combining the information of the tiles with numbers. If a bomb is revealed, the game is lost.

The game features three difficulty levels, which change the size of the board and the amount of bombs randomly placed. Custom boards can also be played with a size of up to 50x50 and chosen amount of bombs. There are four graphical themes and a high-score table to reach, in which the time required to mark all bombs is recorded.

sample_screenshots.caption: The last bomb cannot be decided for sure with the given information
The high-score table is initially empty
The graveyard theme
Hard mode is played on an rectangular board.
Start: an empty board in easy mode

title: KMines

description:
The goal in KNetWalk is to build a working network. On a square board there are several "interlinks", some are straight lines, others bended in 90 degree or having a branch off. On the board are an amount of "servers" and a single link to the internet. The tiles cannot be moved, but by rotating them correctly connections to other links can be established. To solve a level all servers must be connected to the one "Internet" link.

There are four different difficulty levels which have different board sizes and amount of servers to connect: in the "Easy" level there are six servers on a 5x5 grid, and in the highest difficulty level "Very hard" there are 23 servers on a 9x9 board. There can also be custom board of size up to 11x11 usable. The score is calculated by the time used to solve a level and the amount of rotations required. There are high-score tables for each of the difficulty levels and two graphical themes to chose from.

sample_screenshots.caption: The high-score table is initially empty
Custom boards can even be bigger: up to 11x11
"Very hard" level has a big board
A solved board in the alternate difficulty theme
Medium difficulty has a bigger board and more servers

title: KNetWalk

description:
Naval Battle is an unofficial implementation of the board game Battleship. Two players are placing four ships on a 10x10 board, and then try to sink the enemy fleet faster than the opponent. The four ships are in different size, from a small ship only covering a single field up to a 4 fields length carrier. In the fighting phase, each player can place one shot per turn.

The game can be played with a single player against an computer enemy with three different difficulty settings (which in this case means the accuracy). Also, two players can battle themselves over the network with a build-in server component.

sample_screenshots.caption: I have still three ships left, it looks quite good
Placing the four own ships. Ships can be set vertically or horizontally
High-score table with detailed information
After a lengthy bombardment my smallest ship is undetected -- I won!
Starting screen

title: Naval Battle

description:
This compilation contains a hundred batch of games on three CD-ROMs specifically designed for Linux and also includes a copy of Caldera Open Linux Light, as well as four games ported by Loki, which are:

  • Civilization: Call to Power
  • Myth II: Soulblighter
  • Railroad Tycoon II
  • Eric's Ultimate Solitaire CD

Aside from Loki, other games are presented on the disc including:

  • Freeciv
  • Lin City
  • GNU Chess
  • Maelstrom
  • Xasteroids

The menus are included on each disc for information about each particular game.
title: 100 Great Linux Games Volume 1

description: Quadrapassel is a Tetris variant. Your goal is to create as many complete horizontal lines as possible. The lines are made from seven different shapes. The shapes fall randomly from the top center of the screen. Your task is to rotate and move the shapes across the screen to make complete lines. By making complete horizontal lines, you score points and move up levels. As you progress, the speed of the falling blocks increases.

sample_screenshots.caption: A game in progress
About page for an older version still known as Gnometris
Placed a few more blocks making a slight mess
I just cleared a row!
Playing the older Gnometris version

title: Quadrapassel

alternate_titles.title: Mandrake Linux Gaming Edition, featuring The Sims

description:
As the name suggests, this edition of MandrakeLinux Standard Edition 8.1 was specifically targeted for gamers: apart from the usual games included in Linux distributions such as the KDE and Gnome game compilations, this edition also includes the Linux version of The Sims. Additionally, a code for a 3-month subscription to Transgaming's WineX technology - which was also used to "port" The Sims to Linux - was included in the package, enabling gamers to play some of their Windows games on Linux.

This package was initially the only possibility to get the Linux version of The Sims (until Transgaming sold the disc and manuals as an "On Its Own" version themselves later).
title: MandrakeLinux Gaming Edition

description:
Bsdgames is a package of terminal games and amusements that were historically packaged with BSD. It consists of the following games:

  • adventure : The classic Colossal Cave text adventure
  • arithmetic : An arithmetic quiz
  • atc : An Air Traffic controller simulation
  • backgammon : The board game "Backgammon"
  • battlestar : Another text adventure
  • boggle : The board game "Boggle"
  • canfield : The Canfield solitaire card game
  • cribbage : The board/card game "Cribbage"
  • dab : The pen and paper game "dots and boxes", where you must form the most boxes by connecting a grid of dots.
  • fish : The card game "Go Fish"
  • gomoku : The board game "Gomoku"
  • hack : The classic rogue-like; predecessor to Nethack.
  • hangman : The traditional pen and paper word guessing game
  • hunt : A multi-player deathmatch maze game
  • mille : The board game "Mille Bornes"
  • monop : The board game "Monopoly"
  • phantasia : A Middle Earth-themed multi-user dungeon
  • quiz : A quiz game on a variety of topics
  • robots : A strategy/action game to escape a hoard of man-eating robots
  • sail : A multi-player naval combat game
  • snake : A chase game where you must escape a hungry snake
  • tetris : An implementation of Tetris
  • trek : A Star-Trek strategy game
  • worm : A game where you eat to grow longer and try to avoid hitting your own tail
  • wump : The classic "Hunt the Wumpus" game, where you must track and shoot the Wumpus throughout a random cave layout.

Additionally, some versions of this also contain Rogue, which is often removed or separated due to the license preventing commercial use.

This package also contains a number of non-games, which are described below for completeness:

  • banner : Displays large text banner
  • bcd : Reformats input as punch cards
  • caesar, rot13 : Decrypt or create a Caesar cipher.
  • countmail : Counts the amount of mail you have, similar to Sesame Street
  • dm : Dungeon Master: regulates game playing on a shared server
  • factor : Lists prime factors of a given number
  • morse : Reformats input as morse code
  • number : Writes out the words for a give number
  • pig : Pig Latin converter
  • pom : Displays the phase of the moon
  • ppt : Reformats input as paper tape
  • primes : Generates a list of prime numbers
  • rain : Rain drop screensaver
  • random : Picks random lines from a file or generates random numbers
  • wargames : Menu for launching games, similar to the movie. Launches the game name typed in.
  • worms : Moving worm screensaver
  • wtf : Acronym lookup tool

sample_screenshots.caption: Mille: Traveling 50 miles compared to the computer's 200
Cribbage: Failing to count the number of points after a hand
Pig converts the message to pig latin
Rain is a screensaver that displays rain drops
Dab: Almost done a 3 x 3 game

title: bsdgames

description:
xlander is a 3D version of the classic Lunar Lander. The objective is to land your space craft on the target landing site, marked with a flag, using your limited fuel supply and the thrusters on your craft. This version of the game is presented in 3D wire-frame, and you can thrust forward, backwards, left, right or up. A heading indicator will show you the location to the landing pad, while the fuel gauge shows you how much fuel is remaining for your thrusters.

This game was originally released for Unix/X, and was subsequently ported/compiled for several Linux distributions.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting the game
Flying over the moonscape
A successful landing!
Approaching the landing pad

title: xlander

description:
XTetris is a clone of Tetris for the X Window System. Like Tetris, pieces of four connected blocks fall from top of the play area and must be organized as they fall. The goal is to construct horizontal lines of blocks with no gaps. When this happens, all blocks in the line(s) are erased and more space is available to continue play. When the play area is filled to the top with blocks, the game is over.

This specific version is a fairly faithful single-player adaptation of Tetris, with the addition of a piece placement guide/preview below the bottom of the board. It can be run in Black and White and Colour modes, depending on the capabilities of the X Window system it is used in.

From the version history, XTetris has been modified and built by the efforts of several individuals. It was originally created as a X11 port of a non-graphical tetris game for the Xw (HP) widget set. Versions 2.0 and later were ported to the standard Xaw (Athena) widget set and are the most commonly-available versions. These versions report themselves as XTetris 2 in the application window.

sample_screenshots.caption: Further still
Playing a game in B&W mode
About to score a Tetris (four lines cleared)
Starting in B&W mode
Main application window with no game in progress

title: XTetris

description: 3D Pong is a 3D game based on the Atari Pong Arcade classic. It supports one or two players. Each player controls their paddle with the mouse and tries to score by bouncing a ball into the other player's goal just behind the paddle.
title: 3D Pong

description: Aliens is a variant of Space Invaders written specifically for the Linux-based Agenda VR3 personal digital assistant (PDA).
title: Aliens

description:
In Agendaroids your objective is to maneuver a space ship within a field of asteroids, and shoot them into smaller and smaller pieces, eventually destroying them completely.

The game is designed specifically for the Agenda VR3 Linux-based personal digital assistant (PDA).
title: Agendaroids

description: X-Bomber is multiplayer maze-style game where players collect and drop bombs, in an attempt to blow each other up. The last player standing wins.
title: X-Bomber

description:
XPacman is a simplified and somewhat different version of Pac-Man for the X Window System on Linux/Unix. Like Pac-Man itself, you play as a yellow disc which eats pellets around a maze and avoid ghosts. As per the original, there are also power pellets in the maze, which will allow you to eat the ghosts for a limited period of time.

Where this version differs is the maze layout, which is randomly generated on the start of each game. The size of the maze can also be altered using command-line arguments. Power pellet placement can be anywhere, and the number of ghosts can vary based on maze size. On the default size, 8 ghosts are present. Finally, the game does not have any scoring or lives mechanics; if Pac-man is caught by a ghost, the maze automatically resets. If Pac-man clears the maze, a new maze is generated.

sample_screenshots.caption: A slightly smaller maze
A very small "maze"
A different maze layout at the default size
Starting the game at the default maze size
A rather large maze

title: XPacman

description:
xsok is an open source expanded clone of Sokoban for the X-Window system on Linux and other flavours of Unix. It contains three primary level sets:

Sokoban levels are the same levels as traditional Sokoban. The objective is to move each box onto its designated destination. The level is considered completed when this occurs. Each box can only be pushed, not pulled, and multiple boxes cannot be pushed together.

Cyberbox levels are clones of levels from a DOS game of the same name. This mode uses boxes that can only be pushed in a specified direction, as well as pushers that automatically move boxes, one-way arrows and a few other mechanics. Unlike traditional Sokoban, multiple boxes can be pushed together. The objective is to reach the exit, not to place boxes in designated locations.

Xsok levels are unique to xsok. They may combine any combination of the above mechanics, as well as several new elements. In general, all traditional Sokoban boxes must be placed on their designated spots then reach the exit. Some of the additional mechanics in this mode include teleporters, 'no block' or 'no player' squares, and a strength mechanic which controls which types of boxes you can push.

sample_screenshots.caption: One box placed in level 1
Sokoban levels, level 2
Start of the Sokoban levels
A later level in the xsok level set
A later level in the Cyberbox level set

title: xsok

description:
XPat2 is a collection of patience (solitaire) games for the X Window System on Linux and Unix. The rules can vary by specific game, though usually involve organizing the cards into a series of "foundation" piles by rank, removing the cards according to specific collection rules, or organize in some other way. Each game has specific rules about how the cards can and cannot be moved in order to eventually organize/remove them all.

The complete list of included games is as follows:

  • Baker's Dozen
  • Blue Moon
  • Calculation
  • Canfield
  • Free Cell
  • Gypsy
  • Idiot's Delight
  • Klondike
  • Michael's Fantasy (invented for this game)
  • Midnight Oil
  • Modified Canfield
  • Monte Carlo
  • Oonsoo (adapted from Hanafuda cards)
  • Royal Cotillion
  • Seahaven Towers
  • Spider

Rather unusual for a computer solitaire game, the left mouse button will directly move the selected card to the most likely valid destination. To move a specific card to a specific destination, the middle mouse button must be used instead.

This game is based on source from a previous game known as XPat, which was, in turn, based on a Sun Microsystems version of Spider solitaire known simply as Spider.

sample_screenshots.caption: Monte Carlo
Michael's Fantasy, which was invented to test slot rotation features in this specific collection
Klondike is included, of course
Baker's Dozen
Canfield

title: XPat2

description:
xmine is a rather faithful clone of Minesweeper for the X Window System on Linux and various Unix-based Operating Systems. Like the original, the goal is to locate all mines in a grid, by carefully testing squares. After a square is tested, it will report the number of mines in the adjacent squares. Empty squares tested will automatically expand until bounded by squares near mines. Based on the displayed numbers, the user needs to infer the correct location of mines and flag them, before testing additional squares.

Like the original, this can be played in beginner, intermediate, or advanced sizes. It also allows the user to customize a difficulty by setting both the grid dimensions and the number of mines.

sample_screenshots.caption: Stepped on another mine
Starting the advanced game
Accidentally stepped on a mine
Starting the intermediate game
Starting a blank beginner game

title: xmine

description: Xvier is a clone of the Milton Bradley board game Connect Four for the X Window System. The player and computer take turns dropping pieces into a grid. The objective is to end up with four pieces in a row horizontally, vertically or diagonally. This version is rather simple, with only the ability to play against a computer, not another player. The board size and computer difficulty can be changed with command-line arguments.

sample_screenshots.caption: An empty board
The computer won again
A rather symmetric second game
The computer won
Starting a game. I am yellow, the computer is red

title: Xvier

description:
Xmahjongg is an implementation of Mahjong solitaire for the X Window System. A collection of 144 Mahjong tiles is arranged into one of several patterns. The objective is to remove all tiles from the board in matched pairs. The tiles can only be removed when both tiles have at least one site that does not touch another tile.

Various tile layouts and designs can be selected using command-line parameters.

sample_screenshots.caption: I think I'm just about out of moves
Starting with the default layout and tileset
Removing some tiles
Removing more tiles
Removing a couple tiles

title: Mahjongg

description:
X Solitaire is a basic implementation of Klondike Solitaire for the X Window System, using the Motif toolkit. Like most implementations of Klondike, the goal is to sort all cards into four foundation piles by suit, from kings down to aces, where aces are low. Cards can be dragged around individually or in sequences, and can be placed on a card of opposite-colour suit of one rank higher than the selected card. For example, a black 7 can be placed on an red 8 (hearts or diamonds). Cards are initially dealt into seven columns, with an increasing number of cards in each column, and only the top card initially turned face-up. As cards are moved off the face-down cards, they can be turned up and used in play. Additionally, the remainder of the deck is available for use and can be cycled through one card at a time, then moved into play if they match the card placement rules.

This particular implementation is very basic, with no card art and no detection of the win state. When the game is won, it is up to the user to restart the game through the menu. The game does include some options, such as enabling/disabling score and timer support, as well as switching between draw one and draw three modes when pulling cards from the deck.

sample_screenshots.caption: A new, fresh game
Almost won this game
A game in progress
Yup, fully sorted
And all cards are now in the foundation. Since the game does not detect win state, it does not actually do anything when this happens.

title: X Solitaire

description:
The Ace of Penguins is a collection of the following games, for the X Window System:

  • Canfield Solitaire
  • Freecell Solitaire
  • Golf (the card game)
  • Klondike Solitaire, which is referred to as just Solitaire
  • Mastermind: a clone of the code-guessing board game
  • Merlin: a game where 9 squares must be each made the same pattern. Selecting one square also toggles adjacent ones.
  • Minesweeper
  • Pegged: a peg-jumping board game
  • Spider Solitaire
  • Taipei: a Mahjong Solitaire game
  • Thornq: a Solitaire variant by Martin Thornquist

Most are modeled after a similarly-named Windows game, with a few exceptions. Each game uses a similar interface, with embedded help, and keyboard keys to select modes and change options. There is no visible mouse-driven menu during play. All game artwork has a rather visible Tux/free software theme.

Taipei also includes a layout editor for playing with custom board layouts.

sample_screenshots.caption: Playing Minesweeper on a medium board
A different Pegged layout
Showing the help screen for Mastermind
Freecell after a few cards have been moved
Playing a different Taipei layout

title: The Ace of Penguins

description:
XShisen is a Mahjong solitaire game, usually known as Shisen-Sho. The objective is to remove all tiles from the board by selecting matching pairs of tiles. The tiles can be removed if a line can be drawn between the tiles with no more than three orthogonal segments that does not overlap any other tiles. Practically, this usually means that the tiles are on the same side of the game board, or are adjacent, though this simplification is less applicable as more tiles are removed.

This implementation supports three different board sizes:* Regular (18x8)

  • Large (24x12)
  • Huge (36x16)

It also supports playing with or without "gravity". When gravity is enabled, pieces will fall towards the bottom of the screen as they are removed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Another game, on the Huge layout. This time, a different tile set is used.
At the start of the game, all tiles are displayed in a sorted format. This is the Regular layout.
A separate game on the Large layout. This time gravity is enabled, so all removed tiles only result in gaps at the top of the board.
After starting the game, the tiles are shuffled
After removing a few tiles, without gravity enabled. Note the blue line drawn to show the three segments connecting the selected tiles.

title: XShisen

description: Oonsoo is a Solitaire/Patience game played with Hanafuda cards for the X Window System. The game is played with 12 foundation piles, initially with two cards in each. Cards can only be moved onto matching suits, and need to be organized in rank order. After organizing the initial cards, additional cards can be dealt from the deck, one on each pile per deal. The game is won when all twelve piles contain a single suit each, in its corresponding rank order.

sample_screenshots.caption: A game has been started
The about dialog box
The in-game help includes a handy diagram of suits and rankings for Hanafuda cards
The same game, after sorting a few cards and dealing another row of cards

title: Oonsoo

description:
XMille is a re-implementation of the Parker Brothers Mille Bornes card game for the X Window System. The objective is to be the first to reach a distance of 700 kilometers, which can be optionally extended to 1000 kilometers by the first player to reach it. Each turn consists of pulling a single card from the deck, followed by either playing or discarding a card. Distance is accrued by playing cards corresponding to the distance to travel. Other cards consist of hazards/conditions (e.g. flat tire), counters to the hazards (e.g. spare tire), and rare protections against hazards (e.g. puncture proof). The game starts with the ‘Stop’ condition active, and a ‘Go’ card must be played before you may move.

This particular version of the game is played solo against the computer.

sample_screenshots.caption: Start of a game
The computer won the race
The computer has caused me to run out of fuel, and each of us has a safety card active.
The race is in progress. I have reached 300 kilometers, while the computer is at 250.

title: XMille

description:
xsol is a solitaire/patience for the X Window System similar to Klondike. The goal is to sort all cards into four foundation piles by suit, from kings down to aces, where aces are low. Cards can be dragged around individually or in sequences, and can be placed on a card of opposite-colour suit of one rank higher than the selected card. For example, a black 7 can be placed on an red 8 (hearts or diamonds). Note, however, that there is no visual indication of dragging, and the cards are only moved once the mouse button is released.

Cards are initially dealt into seven columns, with an increasing number of cards in each column, and only the top card initially turned face-up. In this particular variant, any face-down cards are hidden directly under the face-up cards and cannot be seen until cards above are moved off them. Once this happens, they can then be used in play. Additionally, the remainder of the deck is available for use and can be cycled through one card at a time, then moved into play if they match the card placement rules. This version only permits the deck to be flipped through once. After the deck is exhausted, and no more moves are available, the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Organized a few cards, and started one ace on the foundation.
The end state for my game. The deck has been exhausted, and no more moves are available.
Starting a game

title: Xsol

description:
Uos is a free internet-based multiplayer 3D roleplay-based learning environment, where you can learn what an ID card is, how to apply for one, what a bank card is and how to use it. It also explains about PIN codes, state levy, dividends, digital prescription, salary, income tax, VAT, etc. In addition, the game has a lot of tasks and other fun activities, like rally, paintball, designing clothes, publishing a magazine, pets, etc.

The game runs on Unity and the development cost about €286,000; it was funded by the Estonian government to teach citizens in a playful manner. Character speed regulation and high scores are sent from the client to server without checks, this allows speedhacking and editing of scores; however rarely admins have corrected leaderboards.

The game was played internationally for a moment in 2019, when YouTuber "aksually" made a video showcasing and criticizing the game.
title: Uos
